@graph.definition: Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Anticlockwise P–T paths are those in which the thermal maximum (peak temperature) is reached prior to the peak pressure being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect high (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.

Describes the apparent direction of the sequential path on a P–T diagram, where the x-axis is temperature, and the y-axis is pressure (with positive ordinates above the abscissa). Clockwise P–T paths are those in which peak pressure is reached prior to peak temperature being attained. These P–T paths generally reflect burial and subsequent heating under low to intermediate (geo)thermal gradient and heat flow conditions.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature decreases (i.e. cooling) over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains constant as temperature increases (i.e. heating) over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant over a period of time (t), during a metamorphic event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while the pressure decreases over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains constant while pressure increases over a period of time (t).
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic cooling event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the pressure (P) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic heating event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic compression event.
Metamorphic conditions under which the temperature (T) remains nearly constant over a period of time (t) during a metamorphic decompression event.
The pressure(P)–temperature(T)–time(t) path for a specific metamorphic event is unknown.
